Elliotte,

Parameterized tests violate an assumption in JUnit that some of =
which JUnit GUIs depend on, that tests can be uniquely identified by a clas=
s and method name. However, I can see that they are potentially useful. One=
 question is whether to add functionality to JUnit only at a speed the test=
 runners can match or march ahead, accepting that temporarily-poor GUI supp=
ort is the price of architectural progress. Having not changed JUnit much i=
n years, I am ready to move forward.

Here is a revised parameterized test =
proposal for comment. Three things have changed.
  * The class is now annot=
ated with a class used to run it: @Factory(Parameterized.class). This seems=
 like a very general mechanism to me. For example, I was able to write a te=
st runnerlet to run JUnit 3.x AllTests in a few minutes. Would JUnit extend=
ers find this annotation generally helpful?
  * The data comes from a stati=
c method instead of a static field. A method seemed more general than a fie=
ld and is evaluated later, when the test is run instead of when the class i=
s loaded. Totally static data can be simply implemented by a method which j=
ust returns that data.
  * Parameters are passed to a constructor instead o=
f stuffed into fields. This seems more general as well as reducing the numb=
er of annotations by one. One limitation of the current implementation is t=
hat parameterized test classes can only have a single constructor.

Here is=
 an example:

 Factory, because it doesn't create anything. "Runner", perhaps?

ass FibonacciTest {
		@Parameters public static Object[] data() {
			return=
 new int[][] {{0, 0}, {1, 1}, {2, 1}, {3, 2}, {4, 3}, {5, 5}, {6, 8}};
		}
